properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall tonight through Thursday night. A few rounds of thunderstorms will soak the region tonight through Thursday night. Total rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm are expected across the area. Severe thunderstorm watches and warnings remain in effect for some regions across far Northern Ontario, mainly due to torrential downpours giving locally higher rainfall amounts of 50 to 75 mm. Environment Canada continues to closely monitor this situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T21:19:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-18T05:20:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3310525398.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot weather is expected for the end of the week. Time span: today and Friday. Maximum Temperature today: 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 32) Minimum Temperature tonight: 19 degrees Celsius Maximum Temperature Friday: 32 degrees Celsius (Humidex 35) Locations: Prince Edward Island Remarks: Cooler temperatures will occur along parts of the coast, where winds blow onshore. Temperatures will turn cooler on Saturday. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T23:46:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-18T07:47:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4023694653.2020
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot weather is expected for the end of the week. Time span: today and Friday, continuing on Saturday over southern sections. Maximum Temperature today: 30 to 34 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 36). Minimum Temperature tonight: 17 to 20 degrees Celsius. Maximum Temperature Friday: 33 to 35 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 39). Locations: Inland areas of Nova Scotia. Remarks: Cooler temperatures will occur along parts of the coast, where winds blow onshore. Temperatures will return to more seasonal values over northern Nova Scotia on Saturday, however, hot weather is expected to continue over southern areas. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T23:45:01-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heat continues tonight. Overnight lows in the upper teens to low twenties are expected for tonight, providing little relief from today's hot temperatures. A cooler airmass will arrive from the west on Thursday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures reaching 27 degrees Celsius are expected. A prolonged period of above normal temperatures and high humidex values will continue in the Kugluktuk area tonight into Thursday before coming to an end by Friday. The overnight low for Kugluktuk tonight is forecast to be 15 degrees Celsius and Thursday's daytime high temperature will approach 27 degrees Celsius with a humidex of 29 degrees. The current record high temperature for Kugluktuk on June 18 is 26.7 degrees Celsius, set in 1935. Records for this area began in 1930. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T19:28:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-18T03:29:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3800766622.2020
Area: Kugluktuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures reaching 35 degrees Celsius combined with overnight lows near 20 degrees Celsius are expected for the next 3 days. Hot weather is expected to continue. Time span: continuing into Friday and Saturday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 31 to 35 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36 to 39) on Thursday and Friday. Cooler conditions are expected along parts of the coast. Minimum overnight temperatures: 20 to 23 degrees Celsius. Locations: New Brunswick. Remarks: Very high temperatures will dominate over New Brunswick for the next two days. The warmest conditions are expected to occur over most areas today and Friday. Cooler temperatures are expected over northeastern parts of the province on Saturday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T23:43:08-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 2:22 a.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a dangerous thunderstorm capable of producing strong wind gusts, pea to dime size hail and flooding rain. A slow moving line of thunderstorms moving northeastwards across southeastern Manitoba will bring torrential rainfall to the region. Localized rainfall accumulations in excess of 100 mm are possible. Gusty winds and hail are also possible with these thunderstorms. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-06-18T09:29:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-18T07:23:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3996060361.2020
Area: Shoal Lake Reserves, Buffalo Point Res. and Northwest Angle Prov. Forest, R.M. of Piney incl. Sandilands and Sprague
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, damaging hail and torrential rain. A disturbance slowly tracking eastwards is bringing thunderstorms to southeastern Manitoba tonight. Some of these thunderstorms may be severe with torrential rain, strong winds, and/or damaging hail. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T10:59:18-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 11:59 p.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, pea to dime size hail and heavy rain. A north to south line of thunderstorms has developed near the Ontario-Manitoba border and is moving slowly east into the area. Torrential downpours are likely, which will lead to rainfall amounts of 50 to 75 mm in areas that receive two or more thunderstorms in a row. Locally higher rainfall amounts of 75 to 100 mm are possible near the Manitoba Border tonight. Wind gusts to 100 km/h are also possible. ### Heavy downpours are likely to cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes.
Expires: 2020-06-18T08:29:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-18T05:00:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2424466226.2020
Area: Pikangikum - Poplar Hill - MacDowell, Red Lake - Woodland Caribou Park, Kenora - Grassy Narrows - Whitedog, Sioux Narrows - Nestor Falls - Morson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Squalls with wind gusts up to 50 knots, frequent lightning, waterspout activity and poor to very poor visibility in thunderstorms heavy at times are expected or occurring in the area. A north to south line of severe thunderstorms will slowly move across the lake tonight. Squalls to 50 knots are possible. Visibility may suddenly be reduced to near zero in torrential downpours. Mariners should remain in port until the thunderstorms pass by. ### Keep in mind that waterspouts cannot be seen at night and may strike suddenly. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
Expires: 2020-06-18T08:29:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-18T05:04:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2469012373.2020
Area: Lake of the Woods

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. Hazards: - Torrential downpours giving local rainfall amounts of 50 mm in an hour or less - Damaging wind gusts to 100 km/h Locations: Portions of Northwestern and far Northern Ontario near the Manitoba border. Timing: Overnight into Thursday morning ### Hail is also possible. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 1:47 a.m. CDT (2:47 a.m. EDT), Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. A cluster of thunderstorms in the region is producing torrential downpours. Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 75 mm are likely in locales that get two or three thunderstorms in a row. Some of the thunderstorms contain frequent lightning and wind gusts possibly to 90 km/h. ### Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops.
